display_asset.caption: Deana Heisler and her daughter Taylor Heisler in Colorado Springs, Colo., on Monday.
display_asset.credit: Jerilee Bennett/The Gazette, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A storm, packing blizzard-like conditions and lightning strikes, deposited several inches of snow in Colorado and Nebraska, and knocked out power to thousands of residents.

display_asset.caption: O.J. Simpson is expected to, once again, be the subject of widespread attention with the debut of a new television show about his trial.

summaries.body: “The People v. O. J. Simpson: American Crime Story” begins on FX on Tuesday night. Read original coverage from The Times about the trial's key points, main players and more.
Florida is grappling with how to change its death penalty law in the wake of a Supreme Court ruling that called part of the law unconstitutional.

display_asset.caption: Joel A.Wright, second from left, was arrested at the San Diego airport on Friday.
display_asset.credit: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A seminary student from Ohio was arrested while traveling to Mexico to find children under the age of 4 to sexually assault, the authorities said.

display_asset.caption: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, right, and Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, at Downing Street in London on Sunday.

summaries.body: A package of concessions intended to persuade Britons to remain in the European Union was released, in a move that could lead to a referendum in June.

display_asset.caption: Rihanna’s new album “Anti” entered the Billboard chart at No. 27 — her lowest debut position.

summaries.body: Rihanna's new album opened relatively low on the Billboard chart, but the one million free downloads released by the Tidal streaming service still earned it a platinum certification.

display_asset.caption: Myron Beldock, right, with the mother of Yusef Salaam, one of the five defendants in the Central Park jogger case, in 2002.

summaries.body: Myron Beldock, a civil rights lawyer who won freedom for wrongly convicted men, including the former boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, has died at 86.

display_asset.caption: Babyface

summaries.body: The organization behind the Grammy Awards is forming a political action committee to lobby Congress on copyright and royalties issues. Babyface is among the "ambassadors."
A start-up is offering a subscription service to frequent fliers, allowing them to pay a monthly fee for flights. The cheapest plan is $1,500 per month.
A Picasso bust whose ownership is disputed will go to the Gagosian Gallery until the conflict between the dealer Larry Gagosian and the Qatar royal family is adjudicated.

display_asset.caption: Bill Cosby, in December, after his arraignment hearing in Elkins Park, Pa.
display_asset.credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

summaries.body: While most eyes will be focused on Bill Cosby during his court hearing Tuesday, the real drama might unfold between rival lawyers who could face off in cross-examination.
The Dutch police are training eagles to snatch rogue drones out of the air.

display_asset.caption: Hossein Nayeri was led back to jail on Sunday after he was recaptured.
display_asset.credit: Orange County Sheriff's Department, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A crucial turning point in the capture of escapees from a California jail was two fugitives' argument over whether to kill a cabdriver they had kidnapped.

display_asset.caption: Antonio Pacheco raised a sign supporting other Uber drivers at a protest on Monday in Queens.
display_asset.credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times

summaries.body: Hundreds of Uber drivers gathered at the company's New York headquarters to oppose fare cuts. "They call us partners," one driver said. "But they're treating us like slaves."

display_asset.credit: Loic Bernardin/Marine Nationale, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A bold operation spared an out-of-control cargo ship without crew members onboard from slamming into the French coast.

display_asset.caption: Gregory’s Anderson’s lawsuit provides a peek inside Yahoo’s controversial quarterly performance review system.
display_asset.credit: Laura McDermott for The New York Times

summaries.body: A former Yahoo manager who lost his job filed suit in California on Monday, saying the company's employee-ranking system is discriminatory and violates the law.

display_asset.caption: Benoît Violier in 2012. The French-Swiss chef was found dead on Sunday at his home in Crissier, near Lausanne, Switzerland.

summaries.body: The French-Swiss chef Benoît Violier, who ran a restaurant in Switzerland that was named the world’s best, has died in an apparent suicide, the police said. He was 44.

display_asset.caption: Michael J. Feeney

summaries.body: An ex-reporter for The New York Daily News, Michael J. Feeney, died from complications from a staph infection just before he was set to start a job at CNN. He was 32.

display_asset.caption: A driver was killed after a tree fell across multiple lanes of traffic and crushed her car in Pacific Beach, Calif., on Sunday.
display_asset.credit: John Gastaldo/San Diego Union-Tribune, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A powerful storm tore off rooftops and knocked out power to thousands of people in San Diego and Los Angeles. A driver was killed after a tree crashed onto her vehicle.

display_asset.caption: Pep Guardiola, left, will replace Manuel Pellegrini as Manchester City’s manager beginning next season.

summaries.body: Manchester City soccer club announced that it has signed Pep Guardiola, a managerial superstar at Barcelona and Bayern Munich, to take over next season.

display_asset.caption: A branch of the Hu Da hot pot restaurant chain in Beijing. Hu Da is one of at least 36 restaurants across China that have been investigated for illegally using poppy capsules as seasoning.

summaries.body: At least 36 restaurants across China were investigated for adding poppy capsules and other illegal ingredients to food to make it more addictive, the state news media said.

display_asset.caption: “Why do people want to get stuck in the past?” asked Anna Wintour, Condé Nast’s artistic director.

summaries.body: As artistic director, Anna Wintour has made a rash of changes at Condé Nast in an effort to keep its many magazines relevant, but they have left some employees reeling.

display_asset.caption: Myanmar’s newly democratic government has banned the export of raw timber, to help fight deforestation. But that has idled thousands of the elephants that toil in the logging industry.
display_asset.credit: Produced by By JONAH M. KESSEL
keywords: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

sectionFrontImages.caption: Mahouts and their elephants at their camp. Experts say that hard work has kept Myanmar’s elephants relatively healthy.
sectionFrontImages.credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times

display_asset.title: Myanmar’s Unemployed Elephants

summaries.body: Myanmar's recent effort to fight deforestation has idled thousands of elephants that toil in the logging industry.

display_asset.caption: The remains of a house on Crotona Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx after a fire last week. David Gonzalez, 64, was killed in the blaze.
display_asset.credit: Amir Levy for The New York Times

summaries.body: Two deadly fires in the Bronx have raised concerns about people illegally living in vacant properties.
The ride-sharing service Uber is experimenting with leaving Bop It toys in back seats to distract intoxicated passengers.
The ability to recall every moment from your life is known as “autobiographical memory,” and some researchers say it can be learned. But there are some major downsides.

display_asset.caption: Alexis Bledel, left, and Lauren Graham in “Gilmore Girls” in 2002.

summaries.body: Netflix is producing a limited revival of "Gilmore Girls" that will reunite Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel and be overseen by the series creator, Amy Sherman-Palladino.
A man who was arrested with two guns at a Disneyland Paris hotel on Thursday has no known links to terrorism but was still being detained, the French police said.

display_asset.caption: Shaun White competing in the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

summaries.body: The Winter X Games have begun in Aspen, Colo., but their biggest star, Shaun White, was "not invited." And nobody is saying why.

display_asset.caption: David Granger, editor in chief of Esquire magazine, in 2012.
display_asset.credit: Robert Caplin for The New York Times

summaries.body: David Granger, the editor of Esquire since 1997, will leave the magazine on March 31 and will be replaced by Jay Fielden, the editor in chief of Town & Country.
